Graphical abstract The iodine redox chemistry strategy is demonstrated to facilitate reversible reaction of SiO x , remarkably improving the initial Coulombic efficiency of C/SiO x anode from 57.1 % to 88.5 % at 0.1 A g−1, together with considerable high capacity and cyclability. C/SiO x anode with higher capacity and lower lithiation potential has been recognized as a next-generation alternative to graphite for high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries. However, C/SiO x suffers from low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE), which significantly hinders its practical application. Herein, we reported a straightforward iodine redox chemistry strategy to realize highly reversible Li storage behavior and remarkably enhanced ICE of high-capacity C/SiO x anode toward long-life lithium-ion batteries. Specifically, I2 is introduced into porous C/SiO x via simple fumigation to synthesize their composite (C/SiO x @I), in which I2 can effectively inhibit the irreversible lithiation reactions of SiO x through redox reaction. Further, redox reaction intermediates of LiI3 and LiIO3 can inhibit the decomposition of electrolyte and LiPF6, thereby reducing the thickness of the solid-electrolyte interphase film. Consequently, the obtained C/SiO x @I exhibits a considerable capacity of 1241 mAh g−1 with an improved ICE of 88.5 % at 0.1 A g−1 and impressive cyclability, showing capacity retention of 95 % after 700 cycles at 5.0 A g−1. Besides, the C/SiO x @I with a 12 % addition ratio can greatly enhance the capacity of graphite from 352 to 454 mAh g−1, with negligible impact on its ICE. When the addition ratio is 9 %, the energy density of the 18,650 cylindrical battery composed of graphite and Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 can be enhanced by approximately 25 Wh kg−1. This study opens a new avenue for developing high ICE in SiO x -based anodes for high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries. Keywords Initial coulombic efficiency Iodine redox Lithium-ion battery C/SiO x anode 1 Introduction Graphite is currently the most widely used commercial anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) [1]. Nevertheless, its theoretical specific capacity is capped at 372 mAh g−1, which is insufficient to meet the high-energy-density and high-power-density demands of applications for electric vehicles, hybrid vehicles, and portable electronic devices [2]. In this context, there is an urgent need to develop high-performance anode materials to replace graphite [3]. Among the alternative electrode materials, the C/SiO x anode is particularly appealing due to its enhanced safety and high theoretical capacity [4]. During the initial lithiation process, SiO x reacts with metallic Li to in situ form Li2O, Li4SiO4, Li2Si2O5, and Si nanoparticles [5]. Of these, Li4SiO4 and Li2O, being electrochemically inert, can effectively prevent the agglomeration of Si nanoparticles and buffer the volume expansion during repeated charge/discharge processes [6]. Moreover, the carbon skeleton in C/SiO x composites not only improves the electronic conductivity of SiO x but also mitigates its volume expansion [7]. However, the formation of irreversible phases like Li2O and Li4SiO4 during the initial cycle, along with a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film on the C/SiO x surface, consume a large amount of lithium, resulting in a low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE), typically below 60 % [8], which severely restricts its large-scale commercial application. Recently, several key strategies have been proposed to overcome these bottlenecks of the C/SiO x anode, including structural design [9], reduction of the O/Si ratio [10], and thinning of the SEI film [11]. The creation of nanostructures and pore structures can provide an interlinked porous network structure, which prevents the formation of irreversible lithium storage sites and boosts the ICE of the C/SiO x anodes [12]. Representatively, a coral-like nanostructured silicon composite (c-nSi/SiO x @C y ) was manufactured by etching Al60Si40 with H2SO4 and subsequently depositing a carbon layer on its surface. When employed as an anode in LIBs, this c-nSi/SiO x @C y anode achieved an ICE of 85.5 % [6]. A higher O/Si ratio in the C/SiO x anode leads to more Li+ consumption via the formation of inert components such as Li4SiO4 and Li2O, resulting in a low ICE [13]. The O/Si ratio of C/SiO x composites can be reduced by refining the reduction conditions or utilizing strong reducing agents. For instance, Wen et al. used Mg as a reducing agent to increase the ICE of the C/SiO2 anode to 72.9 % [14]. Additionally, preparing a layer of metal oxide or metal phosphate film (such as Al2O3 [15], ZrO2 [16], CeO2 [17], Li3PO4 [18], AlPO4 [19], and Al/Al2O3 [20]) on the C/SiO x surface can also improve the structural stability and inhibit the formation of an overly thick SEI film and dissolution of the electrode material, boosting the ICE [20]. Despite these advancements, these strategies cannot efficiently prevent the irreversible lithium insertion in SiO x to yield Li2O and Li4SiO4 [21], which remains a barrier to further improvement in the ICE of C/SiO x anode. It has been observed in lithium-iodine batteries that I2 is easily converted into I3 − in organic electrolytes [22]. Lu et al. demonstrated that the reversibility of Li2O can be achieved via the reaction of I3 −/I− redox [23]. In addition, another irreversible substance, Li4SiO4, generated by lithium intercalation of SiO x is a composite of the reversible product Li2SiO3 and the irreversible product Li2O [8]. Upon consideration of these factors, a straightforward iodine redox chemistry strategy was demonstrated to realize highly reversible Li storage behavior and remarkably enhanced ICE of high-capacity C/SiO x anode toward long-life lithium-ion batteries in this work. Specifically, I2 was introduced into rice husk-based porous C/SiO x composite via simple fumigation to prepare C/SiO x @I composite. I2 will form I3 − after being introduced into the electrolyte [23]. During the initial discharge process, I3 − reacts with SiO x to intercalate lithium, forming LiI, LiIO3, and Si. Upon charging, LiIO3 and Si react to produce SiO x and LiI. Subsequently, LiI undergoes the delithiation to form LiI3. This redox activity of I2 can promote the reversible reaction of the SiO x anode and prevent the formation of irreversible products like Li2O and Li4SiO4. The intermediate products, such as LiI3 and LiIO3, also inhibit the decomposition of electrolyte components, including LiPF6. Furthermore, I2 vapor penetrates the pores of porous C/SiO x and adheres to the pore walls, reducing the porosity of C/SiO x composite, which can effectively minimize the formation of the SEI film and thus decrease Li+ consumption during the first discharge process. All of these make the C/SiO x @10%I anode display an excellent ICE of up to 88.5 % at 0.1 A g−1, a high reversible specific capacity of 525 mAh g−1, and remarkable long-term cyclability of 95 % after 700 cycles at 5.0 A g−1. After the addition of 12 % C/SiO x @10%I%I into the graphite anode, the specific discharge capacity of the graphite composite increases to 454 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles with a higher ICE of 93.6 %. In particular, incorporating 9 % C/SiO x @10%I can enhance the energy density of 18,650 cylindrical cells composed of graphite and Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 by approximately 25 Wh kg−1. These findings conclusively demonstrate that the C/SiO x @10%I composite can serve as an effective additive to graphite anodes, thereby enabling the preparation of high-energy-density LIBs. 2 Results and discussion The preparation process of the C/SiO x @I composites is schematically illustrated in Scheme 1 . Firstly, rice husk powder was activated with ZnCl2 to obtain porous C/SiO x under a nitrogen atmosphere. Subsequently, I2 was incorporated into the C skeleton of rice husk-based porous C/SiO x composite using a fumigation method. The composition of the C/SiO x and C/SiO x @I composites was analyzed through thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Fig. 1 a and Fig. S1a). TGA curves show that the mass loss of C/SiO x @I composites between 180 and 300 °C is attributed to the volatilization of I2. These composites contain approximately 8 %, 10 %, and 12 % I2 (Table S1), denoted as C/SiO x @8 %I, C/SiO x @10%I, and C/SiO x @12 %I, respectively. Above 400 °C, the mass decreases significantly due to the rapid combustion of the C skeleton under O2 [24], and is stabilized at 650 °C, with SiO2 as the main residue. Combined with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Table S2), the SiO x weight content in the C/SiO x anode is calculated to be ∼52.1 %. After the introduction of I2, the SiO x content in these C/SiO x @I composites with varying I2 ratios is reduced to 44.17 %, 42.16 %, and 40.56 %, respectively (Table S1). The elemental composition and chemical states of the C/SiO x and C/SiO x @I composites were examined by XPS (Fig. 1b and Fig. S1b). The detection of O, C, Si, and I atoms in the C/SiO x @I composites confirms the successful introduction of I2 during the evaporation-condensation process. The Si 2p XPS spectra of C/SiO x and C/SiO x @I composites can be deconvoluted into four peaks at 103.2 (Si+), 103.5 (Si2+), 104.2 (Si3+), and 104.8 eV (Si4+) (Fig. S2a–d). With increasing I2 content, the O/Si ratio gradually decreases (Table S2), indicating the partial reduction of SiO x during the I2 introduction. Since the theoretical specific capacity of Si is 4200 mAh g−1, a lower O/Si ratio corresponds to a higher specific capacity for the C/SiO x @I electrodes [25]. The I 3d XPS spectrum of C/SiO x @10%I shows two peaks at 620.2 and 647.8 eV, corresponding to I5 − [26], and two peaks at 630.1 and 631.8 eV, corresponding to I3 − (Fig. 1c). These polyanions can provide a large number of active centers to enhance the lithium storage capacity [27]. The C 1s XPS spectrum can be resolved into four peaks at 283.7 (C–Si), 284.1 (C–C), 284.3 (C–I), and 285.4 eV (O–C=O) (Fig. S2f–h). The results demonstrate that a small amount of C–I bonds can be formed during the I2 introduction, which can effectively mitigate the loss of I2 in the LIBs. The phase structure and purity of the C/SiO x and C/SiO x @I composites were analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. The XRD pattern of C/SiO x composite exhibits a broad peak at 26°, indicative of the presence of amorphous C and amorphous SiO x within the composite (Fig. 1d). After I2 adding, the diffraction peak of the C/SiO x @I composites shifts to a smaller angle (Fig. 1d and Fig. S1c), which is attributed to the larger atomic diameter of I (0.266 nm) compared to C or Si. As I2 is incorporated into the carbon layer, the interlayer spacing of the C skeleton increases, causing the diffraction peak to shift to a smaller angle [28]. The expanded C layer spacing is conducive to the diffusion of Li+ and electrons, thereby improving the conductivity of the C/SiO x anode [29]. In addition, this expansion can also reduce dead zones of the lithium storage within C/SiO x @I anode, improving its ICE and cycling stability (Fig. S3). Furthermore, the absence of other impurity diffraction peaks suggests that the as-prepared C/SiO x @I composite is relatively pure. To gain deeper insights into the C skeleton structure of the C/SiO x @I and C/SiO x composites, Raman spectroscopy was conducted. As revealed in Fig. 1(e) and Fig. S1(d), a distinct D band at approximately 1352.0 cm−1 is clearly identified for these composites, which corresponds to the edges and disordered carbon in the C skeleton [30]. Additionally, a G band at approximately 1584.3 cm−1 is observed, associated with the sp 2 hybridized bonds of ordered carbon [30]. The intensity ratio of I D/I G reflects the degree of disorder in the graphite structure. Notably, the I D/I G ratio for all C/SiO x @I composites is higher than that of the C/SiO x composite and increases with the addition of I2, indicating that I2 addition elevates the defect level of the C skeleton [31]. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms for the C/SiO x and C/SiO x @I composites in Fig. 1(f) and Fig. S1(e) display Type IV curves with an H3 hysteresis loop [32]. It is confirmed that the composites have a hierarchical porous structure with both micropores and mesopores, which are beneficial for the transport of Li+ [33]. The C/SiO x exhibits a high specific surface area of 405 m2 g−1 (Table S3), with pore sizes predominantly ranging from 0.3 to 7 nm (Fig. 1f and Fig. S1f). As the I2 content increases, the specific surface area and pore volume of the C/SiO x @I composites progressively decrease, whereas the pore size is enlarged (Table S3). This is because I2 vapor diffuses into the pores of porous C/SiO x and adheres to the inner wall of pores, which causes the micropores of C/SiO x to be blocked and reduces the size of mesopores. Fortunately, the decreased specific surface area reduces the contact between the electrode material and the electrolyte, thereby minimizing side reactions associated with electrolyte decomposition and the formation of SEI film [34]. Low-magnification scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images reveal that the C/SiO x composite has an irregular black lump-like morphology before and after modification (Fig. S4). High-magnification SEM images show that the surface of C/SiO x composites is covered with pores of varying sizes (Fig. S4). With the increasing I2 content, the number of pores on the surface of C/SiO x @I composites decreases, and the pore size increases (Fig. 1g and Fig. S4), which further corroborates the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) results. Additionally, the nanoscale I2 particles are uniformly distributed on the surface of C/SiO x @10%I composite, while the surface of C/SiO x composite is smooth with a legible contour (Fig. 1h and Fig. S5a). The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images in Fig. 1(i) and Fig. S5(b) reveal that the SiO x nanoparticles are homogeneously embedded in the C skeleton, and both the C/SiO x and C/SiO x @10%I composites exhibit an amorphous structure with no obvious crystal lattice (Fig. 1j and Fig. S5c). The interlayer spacing of the C layer is expanded from 0.34 to 0.45 nm after I2 addition (Fig. S5c and Fig. 1j), which can effectively mitigate the volume expansion and particle agglomeration of SiO x and I2 during the (dis)charge processes. Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) images of the C/SiO x further confirm the uniform distribution of C, O, and Si in the carbonization products of rice husks (Fig. S5d), which facilitates mitigating SiO x particles agglomeration during (dis)charge processes and enhancing their electrical conductivity. EDS images of the C/SiO x @10%I composite show that the elements are distributed evenly (Fig. 1k), suggesting that the I2 elements are evenly dispersed in the carbon skeleton. To elucidate the lithium storage mechanism, cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were conducted on the C/SiO x and C/SiO x @10%I electrodes at a scan rate of 0.05 mV s−1 within a voltage range of 0.01–3.0 V (Fig. 2 a, b). It is observed that the C/SiO x anode shows the irreversible reduction peaks at approximately 1.4 and 0.8 V, which are related to the irreversible lithium insertion into SiO x , electrolyte degradation, and the formation of a SEI film on the electrode surface [35]. The pronounced reduction peak at around 0.01 V indicates lithium insertion into the intermediate product Si and the C skeleton [36]. During the delithiation process, the peak at 0.24 V corresponds to the lithium extraction from the C skeleton, while the broad, weak peak at around 1.05 V is assigned to the delithiation of the lithium-silicon alloy (Fig. 2a). For the C/SiO x @10%I electrode, the initial cathodic scan exhibits a notable reduction peak at 1.81 V, primarily attributed to the lithium insertion reaction between I3 − and SiO x , resulting in the formation of LiI, LiIO3, and Si. During the anodic scan, the oxidation peak at 1.02 V is associated with the delithiation of the lithium-silicon alloy and the reaction between LiIO3 and Si, leading to the reformation of SiO x and LiI. The strong oxidation peak around 2.3 V corresponds to the process of delithiation of LiI to form LiI3 (Fig. 2b). After adding I2, except in the region between 0.01 and 0.7 V, there is no complete overlap with the second scan during the cathodic scan, whereas the remaining regions largely overlap with the second scan (Fig. 2b). It is noted that the non-overlapping regions are attributed to the formation of a stable SEI film. Fig. 2(c) and Fig. S6(a) depict the rate performance of the C/SiO x and C/SiO x @I electrodes. All the C/SiO x @I electrodes exhibit a higher reversible capacity compared to the C/SiO x electrodes across the tested current density range. In addition, the reversible capacity of C/SiO x @I electrodes initially increases and subsequently decreases with the increasing I2 content. Specifically, the reversible capacities of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, and 2.5 A g−1 are 1244, 1018, 934, 843, 806, 744, and 644 mAh g−1, respectively (Fig. 2c). It is worth noting that when the current density is increased by 25 times, the capacity retention remains as high as 51.7 %. Additionally, the reversible capacity of the C/SiO x @10%I is basically recovered when the current density is restored from 2.5 to 0.1 A g−1, showcasing excellent rate capability. The galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) profiles of C/SiO x @10%I electrode at various current densities are similar, confirming outstanding stability (Fig. 2d). Fig. 2(e) and Fig. S6(b) display the cycling performance of the C/SiO x and all C/SiO x @I electrodes versus lithium metal at a current density of 0.1 A g−1. The C/SiO x @I electrodes show a significantly higher reversible capacity than the C/SiO x ones (Fig. 2e), with the capacity initially rising and then declining as the added I2 concentration rises. After three cycles, the discharge capacity of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode reaches 1266 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and remains at 1241 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles, with a retention rate of 98.0 %. This performance is markedly superior to those of the other C/SiO x @I electrodes and the C/SiO x electrode. The initial discharge and charge capacities of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode are 1785 and 1580 mAh g−1 (Fig. S6c), respectively, which are significantly higher than those of the C/SiO x @8%I and C/SiO x electrodes. The ICE of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode is 88.5 %, which is higher than that of C/SiO x electrode (57.1 %) and the other two C/SiO x @I electrodes (C/SiO x @8%I of 79.2 % and C/SiO x @12%I of 80.4 %) (Fig. 2f). From the fourth cycle onward, the Coulombic efficiency of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode remains at 100 % up to 100 cycles (Fig. S7). The GCD curves of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode at 0.1 A g−1 show almost complete overlap in all cycles after the first curve, further evidencing high cyclability (Fig. S6d). Compared to previously reported C/SiO x electrodes [7,37–47], our C/SiO x @10%I electrode demonstrates the highest ICE (Fig. 2g), underscoring its substantial industrial advantages. To evaluate the long-term cyclability of C/SiO x @10%I as an anode, cycling performance tests were performed at 5.0 A g−1. As depicted in Fig. 2(h), the reversible capacity of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode does not degrade with cycling and remains at 525 mAh g−1 after 700 cycles, with a capacity retention rate exceeding 95 %. To examine the effect of I2 introduction on the cycling stability of C/SiO x , the cross-section of electrode plates before and after (dis)charging was analyzed by SEM. After 50 cycles, the expansion rate of the C/SiO x electrode is 105.6 % (Fig. S8a), while the expansion rate of the C/SiO x @I electrodes becomes larger and exhibits a gradual increase tendency with I2 increasing (Fig. S8b–d). This additional expansion is attributed to the approximately 49 % volume increase when I2 reacts with lithium to form LiI [48]. Such volume changes can lead to structural instability in the electrode material, which will reduce the cyclic stability of the C/SiO x @I electrodes [49]. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the SEI film on the C/SiO x electrode remains uniform and approximately 7.5 nm thick after 50 cycles at 0.1 A g−1. In contrast, the SEI film on the C/SiO x @I electrode becomes significantly thinner after the introduction of I2. Moreover, as the added I2 concentration increases, the SEI film thickness of the C/SiO x @I electrodes initially decreases and then increases (Fig. 3b and Fig. S8e, f). By the density functional theory (DFT) calculation, it is found that the electron affinities of I3 − and LiIO3 are lower than those of the other electrolyte components including LiPF6 (Fig. S9), indicating that LiI3 and LiIO3 can effectively inhibit the decomposition of LiPF6 and the other electrolyte components, thereby reducing the thickness of the SEI film [50]. However, owing to the volume expansion caused by the lithium insertion into I2, the SEI film on the C/SiO x @I electrode surface becomes damaged, necessitating more Li+ to repair the broken SEI film. This results in a thick and uneven SEI film, thus contributing to a lower ICE, as evidenced by the irregular thickness of the SEI film on the C/SiO x @12 %I electrode (Fig. S8f). The Li 1s XPS spectrum of SEI film on these electrodes clearly reveals the appearance of Li–I peaks after the introduction of I2 into the C/SiO x composite (Fig. S10a–d). With an increase in the I2 adding ratio, the proportion of LiI within the SEI film on the C/SiO x @I electrodes gradually increases, while the fractions of Li2O and Li2CO3 decrease (Table S4). The C 1s and O 1s XPS spectra of these electrodes further corroborate this trend (Fig. S10e–l), once again indicating that the presence of I3 − and LiIO3 can inhibit the decomposition of the electrolyte components and LiPF6. LiI, an excellent Li+ conductor, facilitates the transport of Li+ within the SEI film [51]. However, excessive introduction of I2 results in a higher concentration of LiI within the SEI film. The redox reactions of LiI cause the SEI film to repeatedly form and break, necessitating the consumption of Li+ to repair the film, which in turn results in a decrease in the Coulombic efficiency and capacity degradation of the battery. To further analyze the composition changes of the SEI film after I2 introduction, the time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) was used to measure the microstructure and anion distribution of the interfacial layer of C/SiO x and C/SiO x @10%I anodes after 50 cycles. By comparing the depth analysis curve of these two anodes in the negative mode (Fig. 3c, d), it can be found that the signal intensity of C elements, C-containing anion fragments, and P-containing anion fragments is significantly reduced, while the signal intensity of F elements and their anion fragments decreases slightly, which further demonstrates that the introduction of I2 can effectively inhibit the decomposition of the electrolyte components and LiPF6. Comparing the TOF-SIMS two-dimensional (2D) mappings of these two electrodes (Fig. 3e, f and Fig. S11a, b), it is revealed that the colors of the other negative ion fragments map are darkened except for the I− ion in C/SiO x @10%I, along with a decreased uniformity in the distribution of nearly all these ions. Especially, the main anion fragments from electrolyte solvent and LiPF6 decomposition such as C2H3O2 −, LiCO3 −, LiO−, PF2O2 −, and LiF2 − in the three-dimensional (3D) distribution maps of C/SiO x anode (Fig. 3e) exhibit the higher density than them in C/SiO x @10%I anode (Fig. 3f). After I2 addition, the density of other decomposed anion fragments also decreases, and the spatial distribution uniformity of these fragments diminishes significantly (Fig. S11a, b). Overall, it is indicated that although the introduction of I2 can restrain the decomposition of the electrolyte solvent and LiPF6, it can cause insufficient physical and chemical stability in the SEI layer. Consequently, as the I elements content increases, the expansion coefficient of the C/SiO x @I anode rises. To unravel the electrochemical reaction mechanisms of C/SiO x @10%I and C/SiO x electrodes, ex-situ XRD patterns, HRTEM, and Raman spectra were conducted at special (dis)charge potentials (Fig. 4 and Fig. S12). After the C/SiO x @10%I electrode discharged to 1.8 V, the characteristic diffraction peaks and lattice fringes of LiIO3, LiI, and Si are observed (Fig. 4a), corresponding to the lithiation process of LiI3 and SiO x (ii: 3SiO x + I3 − + 3Li+ + 2e− → xLiIO3 + (3 − x)LiI + 3Si). When further discharged to 0.01 V, the diffraction peaks and lattice fringe of Si are replaced by those of Li13Si4 (Fig. 4b), suggesting that the formed Si converts further to Li13Si4 (iii: 4Si + 13Li+ + e− → Li13Si4). Upon charged to 1.1 V, only the diffraction peaks and lattice fringes of LiI are observed (Fig. 4c), indicating that Li13Si4 has lost Li+ to form Si (iv: Li13Si4 → 4Si + 13Li+ + 13e−), while LiIO3 has reacted with Si to reform SiO x and LiI (v: xLiIO3 + 3Si → 3SiO x + xLiI). When further charged to 3.0 V, the LiI peaks disappear, and the electrode exhibits an amorphous state (Fig. 4d), as LiI delithiates to form LiI3 (vi: 3LiI → LiI3 + 2Li++ 2e−), which is amorphous state. The simulation diagram of the charge and discharge reaction process of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode is depicted in Fig. 4(e, f). In contrast, when discharged to 0.01 V, the C/SiO x electrode shows the diffraction peaks and lattice fringes of Li13Si4, Li2O, and Li4SiO4 (Fig. S12a), indicating the lithiation reactions of SiO x and the byproduct Si [52]. Upon charging to 3.0 V, the Li13Si4 peaks disappear, while Li2O and Li4SiO4 peaks persist (Fig. S12b), suggesting that the lithiation of SiO x to form Li2O and Li4SiO4 is irreversible, which is a major reason for the low ICE of SiO x electrodes [53]. The ex-situ Raman spectra of C/SiO x @10%I electrode during (dis)charge processes were presented in Fig. S13. The main signal observed is the symmetric stretching vibration peak of I3 −, which is located in the range of 115–125 cm−1 (Fig. S13b). During the discharge process, the I3 − peak is initially detected at the first four points [54], and its intensity progressively diminishes, signifying the ongoing reaction between I3 − and SiO x . By the time the electrode is discharged to 1.8 V, the I3 − peak has completely vanished, indicating that all I3 − has been consumed in the reaction, in agreement with the earlier CV curve analysis. Conversely, during the charging process, the I3 − peak reappears around 1.9 V and its intensity gradually increases, which confirms the reverse reaction where LiI is being converted back to I3 −. DFT calculations reveal that when Si is adsorbed onto the LiIO3 (100) surface, the interaction energy (E co) is −3.10 eV. This negative E co signifies that the adsorption of Si onto the LiIO3 (100) surface is thermodynamically favorable. The Si atom forms bonds with two surface O atoms, and as a result of this bonding, these O atoms are pulled away from the surface, creating a SiO2 structure (Fig. S13c). If more Si is added to the LiIO3 (100) surface, all O atoms may bond with Si, ultimately resulting in the reaction LiIO3 + Si → LiI + SiO2. These findings provide further evidence that the introduction of I2 into the C/SiO x composite can facilitate the reversible Li+ storage of SiO x . To validate the stability of C/SiO x @I, ex-situ XRD and HRTEM analyses were conducted on the C/SiO x @10%I electrode at a selected voltage after 700 cycles at 5.0 A g−1 (Fig. S12c and d). The observed results exhibit consistency with those recorded after 50 cycles, suggesting that the C/SiO x @10%I electrode sustains a stable transformation process over an extended duration. As mentioned above, moderate I2 doping can effectively enhance both the Li+ storage capacity and the ICE of C/SiO x , which is attributed to the three synergistic effects. First, I2 introduction expands carbon layer spacing and defects in C/SiO x composites, effectively enhancing Li+ storage sites, promoting ionic/electronic transport, and minimizing dead zones of the lithium storage. Second, this redox activity of I2 can promote the reversible reaction of the SiO x anode and prevent the formation of irreversible substances like Li2O and Li4SiO4. Finally, the intermediate products (LiI3 and LiIO3) can also inhibit the decomposition of electrolyte components and LiPF6, thereby reducing the thickness of the SEI film. The electrochemical behavior of the C/SiO x @I and C/SiO x electrodes was examined using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Fig. 5 (a) presents the Nyquist plots for these electrodes, where the semicircles at high and medium frequencies represent resistance from the SEI (R SEI) and charge transfer (R ct), respectively. The R S stands for electrolyte-derived resistance [8]. The sloping line in the low-frequency region indicates the Warburg impedance (Z w) during the Li+ diffusion process. As the I2 content increases, the diameter of the semicircles initially decreases and then increases. Among these electrodes, the C/SiO x @10%I exhibits the smallest R ct + R SEI value and the largest Z w value, indicating its optimized charge transfer and enhanced Li+ diffusion capability. To further elucidate the kinetic diffusion process of Li+ in active electrodes, we utilized the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) to determine the chemical diffusion coefficient (D Li+). Under a pulse current density of 0.1 A g−1, the C/SiO x @10%I electrode displays a smoother and more consistent voltage plateau (Fig. 5b), demonstrating excellent uniformity and stability. Using Fick's second law (Supporting Information), the D Li+ of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode is calculated to be 6.33 × 10−10 cm2 s−1 during discharge and 1.37 × 10−9 cm2 s−1 during charge (Fig. 5c), which are markedly higher than those of the C/SiO x electrode (3.21 × 10−11 cm2 s−1 during discharge and 1.03 × 10−10 cm2 s−1 during charge, Fig. 5d). This clearly supports that the introduction of I2 can significantly improve the electrochemical conductivity of the C/SiO x electrode. The kinetics of lithiation and SEI evolution was also investigated by in-situ EIS during (dis)charging processes. The C/SiO x //Li half-cells exhibit typical semicircle profiles below 3.0 V (Fig. S14a) with the equivalent circuit shown in Fig. 5(a). Compared with C/SiO x , C/SiO x @10%I manifests a much lower R SEI (Fig. S14b), which indicates kinetically more favored Li+ migration through the SEI layer. After the introduction of I2, the R ct of C/SiO x decreases significantly under the same (dis)charge state, and shows a trend of increasing first and then decreasing with I2 increasing (Fig. S15). The lower R ct further reflects the higher diffusion kinetics. These phenomena can be ascribed to the diminished thickness of the SEI film and LiI incorporated within the SEI film. To gain insights into the exceptional electrochemical performance of the C/SiO x @I electrode, CV curves were plotted at scan rates ranging from 0.1 to 1 mV s−1 and analyzed kinetically. The total charge storage can be attributed to two mechanisms, including diffusion-controlled process and capacitive process [14]. Fig. 5(e) illustrates the CV curves at various scan rates, where the C/SiO x @10%I electrode displays two pairs of redox peaks at 2.51, 1.81, 1.73, and 0.65 V. The peak currents increase with the scan rate while maintaining similar profiles, indicating excellent stability of the electrode. The C/SiO x @I electrode exhibits four distinct redox peaks, compared to only two for the undoped C/SiO x electrode (Fig. S16a), which may be attributed to the introduction of more active sites after I2 addition. Additionally, the relationship between scan rate and peak current is described by the equation: i = aνb , log(i) = blog(ν) + log(a). Here, i denotes the current density, ν denotes the scan rate, and a and b are fitting constants [37,52]. As shown in Fig. 5(f), the b values for Peaks 1–4 are 0.61, 0.65, 0.74, and 0.78, respectively. These values suggest that the C/SiO x @10%I electrode operates under a mixed mechanism involving both diffusion-controlled and capacitive-controlled lithium storage [55]. In contrast, the b values for the C/SiO x electrode are 0.75 and 0.76 (Fig. S16b), indicating that the lithium storage process in this electrode is predominantly surface-capacitive controlled. Furthermore, the relationship i (v) = k 1 ν + k 2 ν 1/2 can be used to quantitatively determine the lithium storage mechanism [56]. In this equation, k 1 ν and k 2 ν 1/2 denote the contributions from capacitive control and diffusion control, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. S16(c), the capacitive contribution of the C/SiO x electrode rises from 48.6 % to 73.7 % as the scan rate increases from 0.1 to 1.0 mV s−1. After incorporated with I2, the corresponding capacitive contribution rates decrease to 22.8 % and 63.2 % (Fig. 5g), aligning with the b value of the electrode. As depicted in Fig. S16(d), the capacitive contribution of the C/SiO x electrode at a scan rate of 0.6 mV s−1 is 65 %, notably higher than that of the C/SiO x @10%I electrode (39.6 %) (Fig. 5h). C/SiO x @10%I composite was used as an additive for the graphite anode of LIBs to assess its commercial application potential. Fig. 5(i) displays the ICE at 0.1 A g−1 and the specific discharge capacity after 100 cycles of graphite with different adding ratios of C/SiO x @10%I composite. The commercially available graphite presents a discharge specific capacity of 352 mAh g−1 with an ICE of 94.3 %. After the addition of 3 %, 6 %, 9 %, and 12 % C/SiO x @10%I composite, the ICE of graphite composite remains relatively stable at 94.1 %, 93.8 %, 93.6 % and 93.6 %, respectively. It is revealed that, with increasing adding ratio of C/SiO x @10%I, the specific discharge capacity of the graphite composite after 100 cycles increases to 381, 403, 431, and 454 mAh g−1, respectively. These results fully demonstrate that the C/SiO x @10%I composite can be effectively used as a desirable additive to graphite anode to prepare high-energy-density LIBs. After the C/SiO x @10%I was mixed with graphite at a doping ratio of 9 %, it served as the anode material. Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 was employed as the cathode material, and then the 18,650 cylindrical batteries with a designed capacity of 1500 mAh were subsequently assembled (graphite/C/SiO x @10%I||Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2) (Fig. 5j). At a (dis)charge rate of 5 C, this graphite/C/SiO x @10%I||Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 full cell exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 1565 mAh (Fig. 5j), and the capacity is stabilized at 1421 mAh after 300 cycles, resulting in a capacity retention rate of 91 % (Fig. 5k). Compared with the graphite||Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 full cell, the addition of 9 % C/SiO x @10%I composite results in an approximate 25 Wh kg−1 increase in energy density (Fig. 5l). 3 Conclusions In summary, the integration of I2 into the C skeleton of the porous C/SiO x composite can achieve a high-performance anode for LIBs. The introduced I2 facilitates reversible reactions of the SiO x anode through its redox activity, effectively preventing the formation of irreversible products such as Li2O and Li4SiO4. Additionally, the intermediate products of the I2-embedded lithium reaction, LiI3 and LiIO3, can inhibit the decomposition of the electrolyte components, including LiPF6. Consequently, the ICE of the C/SiO x composite can be remarkably improved from 57.1 % to 88.5 % at 0.1 A g−1. As an additive, the obtained C/SiO x @10%I composite can increase the discharge capacity of the graphite anode from 352 to 454 mAh g−1 at a 12 % addition ratio, with negligible impact on the ICE of the graphite anode. In addition, adding 9 % C/SiO x @10%I to graphite can increase the energy density of 18,650 columnar cells composed of graphite and Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 by approximately 25 Wh kg−1. This work demonstrates that the C/SiO x @10%I composite is a promising additive for enhancing the energy density of graphite anodes in the development of high-energy-density LIBs. coredata.dc:description: C/SiO x anode with higher capacity and lower lithiation potential has been recognized as a next-generation alternative to graphite for high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries. However, C/SiO x suffers from low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE), which significantly hinders its practical application. Herein, we reported a straightforward iodine redox chemistry strategy to realize highly reversible Li storage behavior and remarkably enhanced ICE of high-capacity C/SiO x anode toward long-life lithium-ion batteries. Specifically, I2 is introduced into porous C/SiO x via simple fumigation to synthesize their composite (C/SiO x @I), in which I2 can effectively inhibit the irreversible lithiation reactions of SiO x through redox reaction. Further, redox reaction intermediates of LiI3 and LiIO3 can inhibit the decomposition of electrolyte and LiPF6, thereby reducing the thickness of the solid-electrolyte interphase film. Consequently, the obtained C/SiO x @I exhibits a considerable capacity of 1241 mAh g−1 with an improved ICE of 88.5 % at 0.1 A g−1 and impressive cyclability, showing capacity retention of 95 % after 700 cycles at 5.0 A g−1. Besides, the C/SiO x @I with a 12 % addition ratio can greatly enhance the capacity of graphite from 352 to 454 mAh g−1, with negligible impact on its ICE. When the addition ratio is 9 %, the energy density of the 18,650 cylindrical battery composed of graphite and Li[Ni0.8Co0.1Mn0.1]O2 can be enhanced by approximately 25 Wh kg−1. This study opens a new avenue for developing high ICE in SiO x -based anodes for high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries.
